abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is highly satisfactory; sustainability is
            likely; institutional development impact is substantial;
            Bank performance is overall satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance is overall satisfactory. Among the lessons
            learned are the following. 1) The close linkages and
            consultations between architects/engineers and education
            specialists ensured the pedagogical suitability of the
            rehabilitated facilities. The project has influenced a
            profound and forward-looking change in the way Romania
            invests in and manages its educational infrastructure
            program. 2) School building characteristics can foster or
            block education reform measures. 3) Community participation
            in ECA middle-income countries has a different focus than in
            other regions/countries - more on consultations, not on
            participation in works. 4) Simultaneous investments and
            on-going works financed by other authorities tend to create
            confusion. The differences between the approach used by the
            Bank and that of other parallel investments need to be
            emphasized in careful communications with other authorities.
            5) This project was among the first risk mitigation
            operations in the HD sector and lessons can be extracted
            from the project design and its implementation, which
            included measures and investments addressing the mitigation
            of the risk of physical injury. 6) A timely decision was
            made to undertake rehabilitations of historical and cultural
            monuments only under a co-financing scheme, with the Bank
            financing only the strengthening costs while local
            authorities would finance the restoration costs; otherwise
            the amounts incurred would have left the other schools under
            the project without necessary funds. 7) Countries in
            transition face property rights issues; claims on school
            buildings or land were satisfactorily resolved by local
            authorities, but they represent sensitive issues and due
            attention needs to be paid to relevant regulations and laws,
            often changing during the process. 8) There were few
            instances in which Local Authorities or other parties
            committed to finance works in addition to project
            interventions, but failed to do so in due time; therefore,
            attention should be paid in the future to such arrangements
            in order to avoid delays in schools becoming fully
            operational, as planned. 9) The realistic and economic
            rehabilitation options adopted under the project and the
            firm cost control confirmed this was a good option. The
            project was able to extend its investment benefits to 31.5%
            more beneficiaries than had been initially targeted. 10) In
            terms of quality of works and goods, lessons include
            increased focus on: (a) architectural designs and more
            precise specifications of materials and fittings to ensure
            they are appropriate and adapted to education facilities;
            (b) more involvement of the designers in the site
            supervision to ensure the quality of construction and
            increase responsibility for the design choices. 11)
            Sustained political commitment due to the general
            recognition of the emergency issues at the top is essential
            in bringing an operation to successful conclusion
            notwithstanding a rough sailing. 12) The continuity of
            staff, combined with a strong presence of staff from the
            field and proactive country managers, has led to very good
            borrower and stakeholder relationships.
